A few stocks swam against the tide of a strong market downtrend Monday and hit new highs. WebMD (WBMD) rose 1.17 to close at 47.44. That was its seventh straight up day. The company says it is seeing increasing mobile demand for its website, which dispenses medical advice and information. The company appears to be engineering a successful turnaround. Earnings…

Software-defined networking is moving to the big bucks stage.Annual global spending by Internet, telecom and other service providers on SDN systems — where software takes a more prominent role in network management — will soar above $15 billion in 2018, with a compounded annual growth rate above 90%, says a new study.The findings by ACG Research, released last month, track above two separate estimates of SDN spending by the other main buyers of the technology, enterprises.The ACG report is good news for companies moving fast into SDN, including VMware (VMW), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR), as well as a rising number of startups, says Paul Parker-Johnson, ACG's practice leader."Cisco, Juniper, VMware and Alcatel Lucent (ALU), and to some degree even Red Hat (RHT) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), may be players, and it's also going to be a mixture of brand-new companies that have made the transition," he said.In 2018, ACG says, service provider spending on SDN systems will reach $15.6 billion, up from $626 million last year.No other projections of service provider SDN spending could be found, but two outfits have projectted SDN spending by enterprises.Market tracker IDC pegged annual global SDN spending by enterprise companies at $3.7 billion in 2016, while Pacific Crest Securities forecast $2.2 billion in spending that year. The ACG study has service provider SDN spending in 2016 at $3.9 billion, with a 146% jump forecast for 2017 and another 62.5% rise in 2018.Service providers might be the most demanding market because they answer to a wide range of consumer and business customers, says Parker-Johnson. For them, the need for speed is perpetual."There is no observable sign that we are decreasing the amount of applications we want to consume — people want their video when they want it and they want their news when they want it," he said.IDC analyst Rohit Mehra says the projection is higher than he would have expected. Service providers usually lag enterprises "in terms of changing infrastructures and technologies," he said. "If you combine the telecom routers and the switches and the optical and the wireless gear globally, $15 billion sounds a little high to me, but it's not out of the ball park."SDN is billed as providing a more flexible network that can move data faster and more efficiently than before. It requires a combination of hardware and software to be effective, says Parker-Johnson.The vendors pursuing SDN "are providing really elegant software to enable the applications at the controller level, and so a company like Juniper or Cisco is going to be making money off both the software and the hardware," he said.As data and cloud computing explode, service providers need ever faster and more flexible networksAnother challenge for service providers is keeping up with mobile users and apps, Parker-Johnson says. "It's causing the operators to look for ways to scale up their networks," he said.Less Than $1 Billion This YearThe ACG study projects service provider SDN spending at $777 million this year, jumping to $1.67 billion in 2015, $3.9 billion in 2016 and $9.6 billion in 2017.Sales will accelerate as more service providers realize they need to upgrade their hardware to better accommodate SDN software, Parker-Johnson says."The reason the growth is so steep is that the application providers and the Internet service providers not only want to deliver their applications and use this really cool software that is controlling the infrastructure, they are also going to be buying switches and routers that are being evolved so they can work with SDN," he said.Cisco, VMware and Juniper will also be competing with Ericsson (ERIC) and Nokia (NOK) in SDN revenues, says Parker-Johnson. "You have some international firms from a network infrastructure point of view going hard after SDN and network virtualization for mobile infrastructures," he said.Last year, Cisco developed its first SDN hardware and software products and expects to start shipping them soon. Some analysts have said SDN could hurt Cisco, Juniper and other networking hardware makers. Parker-Johnson says the ACG study suggests otherwise.IDC's Mehra says the jury is out until at least 2015. It's too early to expect SDN to become a revenue boon for companies like Cisco and Juniper overnight, he says."Many customers are still in the process of sorting out what SDN means to them, so there is not necessarily hundreds of millions of dollars in deals that Cisco would get for SDN," Mehra said.
Red Hat stock plunged more than 10% in midday trading Tuesday, after the Linux provider late Monday gave guidance that lagged Wall Street expectations.
The company's revenue and earnings for its fiscal second quarter ended Aug. 31 beat analyst views, but billings missed.
Red Hat (RHT) is the largest provider of Linux operating system software and competes with the Microsoft (MSFT) Windows operating system in the business enterprise field.
Red Hat said billings in Q2 rose 8% to $376 million, well short of the 14% growth that analysts expected. Billings are a predictor of future revenue.
Red Hat said the lower-than-expected billings growth in part "reflects modest IT spending in Europe."

Red Hat said fiscal Q2 revenue rose 16% from the year-earlier quarter to $374.4 million, which was $2 million above analyst estimates. It reported earnings per share of 35 cents, 2 cents above views and up 25%.
It guided fiscal Q3 revenue in the range of $381 million to $384 million, below consensus estimates of $391 million. It guided earnings per share of 34-35 cents, in line with expectations.

"Consensus and guidance figures imply softer growth than in prior years," wrote John DiFucci, an analyst at JPMorgan, in a research note. "We estimate that new subscription business has slowed dramatically over the past several quarters."

Red Hat (RHT) continues to benefit as more companies migrate from Unix systems to its Linux-based systems. That's the story as the enterprise software firm gets ready to report fiscal second-quarter results after Monday's market close.Red Hat's Linux software products have become a foundation for cloud computing, a system that allows companies to store and access data and applications over the Internet. At the same time, Red Hat is moving into new areas, including software storage, which is also expected to become a major revenue driver for the company in the next few years.For its fiscal Q2, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Red Hat to report a per-share profit, minus items, of 29 cents, same as a year ago. The flat earnings are a reflection of an expected rise in research and development costs as the company moves into new markets such as storage and virtualization software, which allows companies to run multiple software applications on one server.Revenue is expected to reach $322.1 million, up 14.5% from the year-ago period.The company's core business of migrating companies from older Unix-based systems to more cost-effective Linux systems remains strong while new areas such as storage and virtualization software hold promise, Rob Owens, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, said in a Sept. 15 report."The underlying business remains strong and customer interest is accelerating in incremental opportunities with (virtualization) and (storage) potentially being drivers for the company in the longer term," he wrote.In its first quarter, Red Hat's per-share profit of 30 cents was up 25% from the year-ago quarter and beat analyst views by 3 cents. Its revenue of $315 million was up 19% from a year ago and 19% better than what analysts had expected.Red Hat's billings growth was up 16% in Q1. But that wasn't enough for some investors. Shares fell more than 6% on June 21, the day following its earnings release. The stock is up more than 38% this year.For the current quarter, analysts expect Red Hat to produce a per-share profit of 30 cents, 2 cents better than the year-ago period. Revenue is expected to be $340.1 million, up 17.2% from the same period last year.Analysts expect Red Hat will roll out a new version of Linux in December that will integrate its new storage product with its middleware and virtualization software products.Bundling all of the products in one could speed adoption of the storage software, says Trip Chowdhry, an analyst for Global Equities Research."A key reason why a customer is hesitant to buy more pieces (of software) is because the buying experience is complicated," he told IBD. "If you can simplify the buying experience the adoption gets a little better."

Stocks were on a tear in early afternoon trading Friday with volume goosed by options expiration.The Nasdaq stormed into the lead with a 1.1% gain. The S&P 500 was up 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%Traders were giddy after the government reported a revised 4.1% annualized increase in GDP. It was better than expected and the best reading since Q4 of 2011. The preliminary reading had been 3.6%.NYSE volume was running 103% above Thursday's pace and Nasdaq volume was 44% higher.In the stock market today 35 IBD 50 stocks were gainers on the day, and 15 were losers.Volatile Ambarella (AMBA), a maker of chips for cameras, rose 13% on volume running 514% above average. It cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern. The company said it's working with Google (GOOG) on a wearable camera. The stock was at an all-time high.Another IBD 50 stock, drugmaker Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), hit an all-time high. Shares rose 6% after the company said it's buying Gentium (GENT) for about $1 billion. Gentium is an Italian developer of drugs for vascular conditions and cancer.Software developers were in the news. Red Hat (RHT) continued to hold the high ground among S&P 500 stocks with a 19% gain. It reported better-than-expected Q3 results. Tibco Software (TIBX), meanwhile, slumped 13% after reporting disappointing Q3 numbers late Thursday.

Red Hat (RHT) stock surged Friday after the open-source software company reported fiscal Q3 earnings that topped Wall Street views, raised revenue guidance and said its OpenStack cloud-computing initiative had gained traction with customers.

Red Hat stock was up 19% in midday trading in the stock market today, at a 15-month high near 58.40. Shares of Rackspace Hosting (RAX), co-developer of the OpenStack cloud standard, were up 2% in midday trading Friday.

UBS upgraded Red Hat to a buy rating from neutral. At least five other investment banks — RBC Capital, Mizuho, BMO Capital Markets, Needham and Stifel Nicolaus — raised their price targets on Red Hat stock.

"We believe Red Hat is a top rebound story for 2014," UBS analyst Brent Thill wrote in a research report. "We thought three quarters of billings weakness would linger but instead billings rose 19.5% year-over-year. We like the setup as the stock trades off billings growth and strengthening fundamentals."

Raleigh, N.C-based Red Hat late Thursday said profit rose 45% to 42 cents per share for its fiscal Q3 ended Nov. 30, while revenue increased 15% to $396.5 million. Analysts had modeled 35 cents and $383.2 million.
For fiscal Q4, Red Hat forecast revenue of $398.5 million, above consensus views of $394.2 million, and EPS of 37 cents per share, in line with estimates.

"The Q3 report should alleviate concerns about growth, with billings of $452.5 million, up 19% year-over-year, accelerating well ahead of the consensus estimate of $420 million, and raised guidance," said Joel Fishbein, a BMO Capital analyst, in a report. "New products (OpenStack, storage, OpenShift) are showing increased traction, and we continue to believe that revenue could accelerate as these businesses mature and distribution increases."

IBM (IBM), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Dell are among backers of OpenStack, open-source software that connects data centers to cloud services. OpenStack faces many hurdles, including Amazon Web Services' (AMZN) dominance in infrastructure-as-a-service. One plus for the OpenStack camp is that Red Hat, the leading provider of Linux server software and a VMware (VMW) rival, has lined up behind the software standard.
"OpenStack adoption is early, and traction appears to be progressing strongly with several early OpenStack wins," added Fishbein.
Ross MacMillan, an analyst at Jefferies, is looking further ahead.
"Commentary around OpenStack was positive but we still view it as a calendar year 2015 growth driver," he said in a research note.
Bhavan Suri, an analyst at William Blair & Co., also was cautious.

"Our sense is that a number of cloud providers (including IBM and recently announced Dell) are starting to develop more robust hybrid cloud offerings that leverage Red Hat's distribution of OpenStack," he wrote in a report. "We suspect the offering will not be material for at least 12 months, but the early trails are encouraging."

Red Hat (RHT) shares were up a fraction midday Thursday after going on a wild ride after hours Wednesday.

The top provider of services and support tied to open-source Linux late Wednesday reported fiscal Q4 revenue that missed analyst expectations, as did its revenue and earnings outlook for the current quarter, as IBD reported. Q4 earnings per share minus items, however, rose 24% and handily beat Wall Street views.
Still, shares plunged as much as 12% shortly after the release, but by 90 minutes or so later were down only 4%. And the stock opened Thursday down more than 4%, before quickly rising.
The company's results were not as bad as seen at first blush, analysts said in research notes out late Wednesday and early Thursday.

Red Hat's results were "reasonable," but "there was some confusion" at first, William Blair & Co. analyst Bhavan Suri wrote in a research note. Suri said some big deals inked and renewed during the quarter shifting a lot of the billings to revenue that will be booked in later quarters.
Billings growth in Q4 rose 9%, which did miss Susquehanna Financial Group's forecast for 14% growth, wrote analyst J. Derrick Wood. But the billings miss was just a "headline miss," Wood wrote.

"... The off-balance-sheet backlog was well ahead of our estimates," Wood said, "and in fact Red Hat beat our total bookings estimate of $502 million by about $25 million, driven by strength in large deals."

Pacific Crest analyst Rob Owens on Thursday, however, cut his price target on Red Hat shares to 55 from 60. Stock futures muscled higher ahead of Friday's open, aiming to build on what is playing out to be a strong week. Dow futures were 92.3 points above fair market value and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 19 points. S&P 500 futures climbed 7.9 points.

The stock market today sets out with the Nasdaq sitting on a 3% gain for the week, the S&P 500 up 2.9%. The S&P 500 is back above its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq opens nearly 4% above its 50-day line. Whether the indexes can hold the psychologically important 50-day lines of support while weighed down with a heavy load of distribution days, will be a key factor in the current rally.
The economic calendar was relatively quiet. The Kansas City Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey is due out at 11 a.m. ET.

St. Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard and New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley are scheduled to speak this morning. U.S. crude futures continued to struggle, trading down more than 1% and about flat for the week, at just below $40 a barrel. Prices may see some effect from results of the weekly rig count from Baker Hughes (BHI) at 1 p.m.
Nike (NKE) hoisted the Dow with a 4% gain. It announced late Thursday a $12 billion, four-year share buyback program, on top of the current $8 billion buyback, to be completed by the end of 2016.

Management also increased the quarterly dividend 14% to 32 cents and announced a 2-for-1 stock split, effective after the Dec. 23 market close. The IBD 50 stock ended Thursday in a test of support at its 50-day moving average, 4% above a 117.82 cup-base buy point.
Retail industry groups, which have taken a serious beating over the past two weeks, continued to make splashy moves.
Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) spiraled 18% higher after earnings soared past consensus expectations and revenue fell less than forecast.

Ross Stores (ROST) surged 7%. The Dublin, Calif.-based chain reported solid third-quarter results after Thursday's close. The stock closed Thursday 6% above its Nov. 13 low, and 18% below its Aug. 18 high after a double-dip consolidation.

Foot Locker (FL) hopped up 7% after its Q3 sales and earnings cleared analyst expectations. The shoe retailer, with close ties to Nike, finished Thursday up 6% this week, and 20% below its September high.
Williams-Sonoma (WSM) slipped nearly 4% after beating Q3 sales and earnings expectations, but guiding Q4 results below estimates.

Intuit (INTU) rallied nearly 9% before the open. The developer of Quickbooks and TurboTax reported after Thursday's close a fiscal Q1 profit of 9 cents per share, vs. consensus projections for a per-share loss of 4 cents. Revenue growth of 17% trounced expectations and management raised its Q2 EPS guidance above estimates. Shares ended Thursday below a 100.73 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Among the morning's heaviest losses, Mentor Graphics (MENT) unspooled 27% after reporting late Thursday its Q3 revenue and earnings were a shade shy of consensus views. The kicker was Q4 earnings, which management said would come in at less than half of current consensus projections. The developer of automated design software finished Thursday's session just above a 27.48 cup base buy point.Stock futures muscled higher ahead of Friday's open, aiming to build on what is playing out to be a strong week. Stocks added to early gains near midday Friday with tech stocks leading a charge to new highs.

The Nasdaq forged ahead in the stock market today, up 0.9% to a new high. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 held their early highs, and were up 0.5% each. Volume remained heavy, boosted by options expiration trading, up 49% on the Nasdaq and 146% on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Thursday.

Software developers were all over the map in Friday's session. RedHat (RHT) continued to hold the high ground among S&P 500 stocks with a 19% gain. Tibco Software (TIBX) remained down 15% after reporting disappointing Q3 results late Thursday.
Marketing software developer Responsys (MKTG) vaulted 38% higher on news that Oracle (ORCL) planned to buy the San Bruno, Calif.-based company for around $1.5 billion. Oracle shares rose a fraction.
VMware (VMW) snapped up 4% in powerful trade. The enterprise software developer is just below its Oct. 22 high, and not quite 4% above an 87.51 buy point in a cup with handle base.
Makers of three-dimensional printers were posting strong gains. Stratasys (SSYS) climbed 3%, 3D Systems (DDD) more than 2% — both in heavy trade. 3D Systems' move pushed it to a new high.

Accenture (ACN) stock fell nearly 4% in morning trading Friday, one day after the big technology consulting and outsourcing services company's earnings and outlook missed Wall Street expectations, as an executive cited a "lower growth" cycle.
For its fiscal Q4 ended Aug. 31, Accenture reported per-share profit minus items, of $1.01, which missed views by a penny, vs. 88 cents in the year-earlier period.
Revenue rose 4% to $7.1 billion, edging views by $200,000.
For its first quarter, Accenture expects revenue of $7 billion and $7.3 billion, up 2.8% to 4.2%, below views of $7.39 billion.
During a conference call late Thursday with analysts, Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said the company continues to be challenged by a tough macroeconomy.

"At a time where volatility and uncertainty are still the name of the game, we continue to focus on driving our own competitiveness, applying rigor and discipline across the board to increase our efficiency and expand our margins," he said. "And this is giving us the capacity to invest in the business to continue to capture new ways of growth."
But the company's growth path doesn't appear to be getting easier, David Rowland, Accenture's chief financial officer, said on the call.

"For the past four to five quarters, it's clear that our addressable market has been in a cycle of lower growth and this has clearly impacted our growth," he said. "As we look forward, we think it's likely that our overall market conditions won't change much in the near term. In other words, it will be more of the same."
Accenture stock, which hit an all-time high of 84.22 in May, is trading near 73 in the stock marketFriday.

On Monday, Linux leader Red Hat (RHT) also gave a disappointing outlook, in part due to macroeconomic concerns focused on Europe, as IBD reported.Accenture (ACN) stock fell nearly 4% in morning trading Friday, one day after the big technology consulting and outsourcing services company's earnings and outlook missed Wall Street expectations, as an executive cited a "lower growth" cycle.For its fiscal Q4 ended Aug. 31, Accenture reported per-share profit minus items, of $1.01, which missed views by a penny, vs. 88 cents in the year-earlier period.Revenue rose 4% to $7.1 billion, edging views by $200,000.For its first quarter, Accenture expects revenue of $7 billion and $7.3 billion, up 2.8% to 4.2%, below views of $7.39 billion.During a conference call late Thursday with analysts, Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said the company continues to be challenged by a tough macroeconomy."At a time where volatility and uncertainty are still the name of the game, we continue to focus on driving our own competitiveness, applying rigor and discipline across the board to increase our efficiency and expand our margins," he said. The stock market extended its gains in late-afternoon trading Friday, showing continued power that began Wednesday afternoon when the Federal Reserve announced it would begin tapering its bond-buying program.

The Nasdaq led the way, up 1.3%. That's more than 50 points as it cracked through 4100. The S&P 500 grew 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6% Volume was very high on a triple-witching Friday, a day each quarter when options, futures and options on futures simultaneously expire.
In economic news, GDP was revised upward to a 4.1% annualized rate from a previous estimate of 3.6%. Most of the upward revision was the result of consumption being revised upward from 1.4% to 2%.
In the stock market today, 36 IBD 50 stocks were gainers on the day, and 14 were losers.
The worst performer was Winnebago Industries (WGO), down 2%. It lost 14% Thursday after a reporting disappointing sales numbers.

Volatile Ambarella (AMBA), a maker of chips for cameras, rose 13% on volume running 514% above average. It cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern. The company said it's working with Google (GOOG) on a wearable camera. The stock was at an all-time high.

Another IBD 50 stock, drugmaker Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), hit an all-time high. Shares rose 6% after the company said it's buying Gentium (GENT) for about $1 billion. Gentium is an Italian developer of drugs for vascular conditions and cancer.

Software developers were in the news. Red Hat (RHT) continued to hold the high ground among S&P 500 stocks with a 19% gain. It reported better-than-expected Q3 results. Cautious optimism is one way to describe the current state of Red Hat (RHT). That appears to be the message from some analysts who follow the provider of open-source software, which is slated to report its fiscal first-quarter results after the market close Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Red Hat to report a per-share profit minus items of…

Red Hat (RHT) shares were down 5.5% in early trading Thursday after the company late Wednesday reported lower-than-expected Q1 billings and gave a disappointing sales outlook. The provider of open-source Linux and other software and services used in cloud computing and other environments did beat earnings and revenue expectations for its quarter ended May 31, as we reported. Red Hat…

Red Hat's  (RHT) growth engine is showing some signs of sputtering. Shares of the provider of software and services used in cloud computing were down 10% after hours Wednesday, after the company reported first-quarter billings growth that missed analyst expectations, as did its sales outlook for the current quarter. Red Hat,however, reported fiscal first-quarter profit and sales that handily…
Red Hat shares were up 15%, at a 12-year high near 58, early Thursday, after the open-source vendor late Wednesday reported profit and sales that beat analyst views, as did its sales outlook.
Analysts raced to boost their sales estimates and stock price targets for the provider of Linux and other open-source software that fits in well with the cloud-computing trend.

Goldman Sachs maintained a hold rating on Red Hat (RHT) shares, but upped it price target $2 to 50. Its analysts called its a "comeback" quarter and wrote that the results indicate the secular trend of replacing expensive proprietary Unix servers by commodity platforms continues, and RHT is well positioned to benefit from this trend."
Trip Chowdhry, an analyst for Global Equities Research, raised his price target to 55 from 50, and boosted his revenue guidance for the company for the next two years.
The company provides and maintains open-source Linux software for corporate and other enterprise users. It's also been expanding into areas such as storage and virtualization.
Red Hat's subscription software business likely will accelerate as more companies adopt cloud-based computing, says Kirk Materne, an analyst for Evercore Partners.
Cloud computing enables users to store and access data and apps via the Internet, or the "cloud."

"As more and more companies move to the cloud, Red Hat has a potential role in a lot of the big data servers because a lot of them will be running Linux," Materne told IBD Wednesday when we reported the company's results.

For its fiscal fourth quarter ending Feb. 29, Red Hat reported a per-share profit minus items of 29 cents, up 12% from the year-earlier quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 27 cents.
Revenue rose 21% to $297 million, vs. views for $291.2 million.
For the current quarter, Red Hat expects a per-share profit minus items of 25 cents to 27 cents, where analysts had been modeling 27 cents. At the 26-cent midpoint, profit would be up 8%.
The company expects revenue of $307 million to $311 million, up 17% at the midpoint. Analysts were expecting $306.2 million.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) stock fell 11% in early trading Thursday after the maker of virtualization and content delivery software and other cloud computing system products late Wednesday preannounced a Q3 earnings miss. The Santa Clara, Calif., company expects to post adjusted earnings of 68 cents to 69 cents per share. The consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters was…
For many companies, life in the cloud starts with Red Hat.

Founded in 1993, the company has become a leading provider of support and related services for the Linux open-source operating system, which companies often use to build cloud computing-based data centers. That's where users store data and apps that they access via the Internet, or the "cloud."
Red Hat (RHT) is hot. Year-over-year revenue has jumped by at least 20% in the past seven quarters, while per-share profit minus items has climbed by 37%, 33%, 53% and 47% the past four quarters.

Jim Whitehurst, Red Hat's chief executive, sat down with IBD to explain what impact cloud computing might have in the coming year. While he expects Red Hat to ramp up hiring, the move to the cloud may reduce many companies' staffing needs.
IBD: The move to the cloud is a big trend in technology, but is it resulting in more jobs?
Whitehurst: We will add at least 1,000 new people next year. (The company had 4,100 employees as of Aug. 31.)
So we are growing relatively rapidly. A lot of that is based on the success of our software products in a cloud context.
IBD: Will the booming cloud computing industry help lead the economy out of this slow period?
Whitehurst: Companies are finally starting to see significant productivity gains from technology, so they are able to grow without hiring as many people.

We are hiring, and I'm sure companies like Amazon (AMZN) and others who provide cloud computing are hiring. But I think that is a drop in the bucket relative to the productivity we are providing enterprises, and that again leads to, unfortunately, slower job growth.
IBD: Many companies continue to shy away from the cloud because they don't want their data and apps residing in distant centers. Is the industry solving the security problem?

Whitehurst: I feel very confident that the technologies (to do this) are already in place. There's no question that large centralized data centers can do a better job of physical security and cybersecurity with encryption and security experts on staff. Most of the issues you have with security start off with a human error, and change takes time. There are mistakes in that process. Over time, we will get there.
IBD: Businesses often slow their spending in presidential election years, until the results are in. Do you expect that to happen in 2012?
Whitehurst: No. We are finally starting to see significant productivity gains with information technology.
In the mid-1990s there was no perceivable increase in productivity from IT.
Now we're seeing a lot of it. I think most companies are investing in IT to continue their double-digit earnings growth.
I do think an election cycle would have some impact. But I think companies have a lot of money sitting on the sideline. If people feel comfortable, you'll see continuing investment.
IBD: Cloud vendors count on growth in Europe and other parts of the world that are having economic problems. Can tech keep growing in problem regions?

Whitehurst: If technologies are fundamentally taking costs out, even in a difficult economic environment people will invest. Cloud technologies in general save customers money and therefore I expect it to hold up very well even in very troubled regions.
IBD: What will happen to the U.S. and global economies in 2012?
Whitehurst: You will see modest growth in the 2%-ish range, so nothing we really get excited about but certainly not dipping back toward recession.
Corporate balance sheets are very strong. There's a lot of cash out there. Earnings and earnings momentum have been very strong.
The problem is we still have consumers and governments dramatically overleveraged and that is going to keep us from truly being able to blow out to a superghigh growth rate.
But corporate earnings will continue to remain strong as companies leverage technology for productivity.
IBD: What will be the big tech trends in 2012?

Whitehurst: The big trend is really a paradigm shift in the way technology will be delivered and deployed. We are now finding that small devices are more effective, and that is why you see this thing called (the) cloud.

It's likely that if you bought a washing machine in the last two or three years, it has a microprocessor more powerful than your first computer. In the future, your car's engine will be hooked up to the (wireless) system in your house and it will download the latest updates to see the way your gas is being used based on the weather conditions. Dishwashers and washing machines will also be connected (to the home network). This meganew network explodes the need for computing on the back end, in the cloud. I call it a paradigm shift from client servers to this new generation.For many companies, life in the cloud starts with Red Hat.Founded in 1993, the company has become a leading provider of support and related services for the Linux open-source operating system, which companies often use to build cloud computing-based data centers. That's where users store data and apps that they access via the Internet, or the "cloud."Red Hat (RHT) is hot. Stocks finished near their session lows and firmly in the red Monday, as early gains quickly evaporated. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video! The Nasdaq shed 1.3%, the S&P 500 1.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Turnover decreased sharply across the board from Friday's expirations-driven pace.…
After closing in a tailspin, the market was disappointed with results of two notable big caps after hours.

Business software giant Oracle (ORCL) said its Q3 earnings rose 9% to 38 cents a share, matching estimates. Sales grew 16% to $6.4 billion. If not for the integration of Sun, quarterly sales would have jumped only 7%. Oracle acquired Sun in January for $7.4 billion.
"The Sun integration is going even better than we expected," Oracle President Safra Catz said in a prepared statement.
Shares were down 1% in after-hours trading.

Accenture (ACN) fell 2% after the company said Q3 earnings slipped to 60 cents a share, missing views for flat earnings. Revenue fell 2% to $5.18 billion in U.S. dollar terms. The Irish company's revenue fell 8% in the local currency.
No notable stocks report before the close Friday, but there will be economic data to watch.
Before the bell, final Q4 GDP figures are expected to be released. The Street expects 0.4% growth. Shortly after the open, consumer sentiment data will be announced.
Weak Ending Wipes Out Gains For U.S. Stocks
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks ended mostly lower Thursday, as weakness persisted throughout the afternoon.

The Dow closed fractionally higher. The Nasdaq fell 0.1% and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%. The NYSE composite shed 0.3%. Volume was higher across the board, according to preliminary data. At the day's high, the Dow was up 1.4% and other indexes were up at least 0.9%.
A handful of strong earnings put investors in a buying mood early, but the rally faded.
A Treasury bond auction showed weak demand, pushing the buck higher.

Still, a few stocks broke out, including China Automotive Systems (CAAS), which passed its buy point of 24 from a sloppy, deep cup-with-handle base. The maker of power steering systems topped earnings expectations.
Amazon (AMZN) also passed a buy point. The Internet retail giant gained 7%, passing its 134.30 cup-with-handle buy point.
U.S. Stocks Ease Further From Highs; Natural Gas Producers Take Hit
